Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Smart RF/Microwave Components using Nano-Film Slow Wave Elements

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective
The objective of this research is to develop compact multifunctional radio frequency and mmwave devices based on nano-film slow wave elements. The approach is to carry out a systematic material and device study include investigating and modeling of low loss slow wave transmission line elements; exploring fundamental science and characterizing tunability of nano-scale patterned Permalloy and Barium Strontium Titanate thin films; designing inductance and capacitance tunable slow wave elements; and demonstrating highly efficient, compact, multifunctional RF devices and components.

Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit of this research includes new architectures of tunable slow wave elements enabled by nano patterned thin films; design and unique process development of 3 dimensional smart slow wave elements on multi-layer flexible polymer substrate; broadband characterization of nano scale patterned Permalloy and Barium Strontium Titanate; and multi-band RF Passive components include a Branch-line coupler, a bandpass filter and a phased array antenna. All the device concepts presented here are unique and the envisioned tunable slow wave elements and their RF device applications will provide a major breakthrough in the field.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of this proposal include the integrated education and research in various ways, such as a new course, recruiting underrepresented and minority engineers at the University of South Carolina, outreach activities and a web based e-museum entitled Smart RF Electronics to inspire young generations interest in engineering. The technical and societal impacts will occur in diverse areas of science and engineering such as telecommunications, medical imaging, and even wireless environmental monitoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern wireless communications and radar systems are required to be miniatured in size and operate at multiple-frequency bands in order to provide the enhanced and multifunctional performances. Frequency-agile and multifunctional circuits are highly desirable in communications systems, radars, sensor networks, and biomedical devices. Tunable elements are the key fundamental components in these frequency-agile and multifunctional systems. The implementation of multi-band RF and microwave circuit topology has become a hot topic with various techniques such as RF MEMS, varactors, ferroelectric, and ferromagnetic thin films.  We are interested in the development of fully electrically tunable RF passives with the miniaturized slow wave transmission line elements enabled by the integration of both ferromagnetic and ferroelectric thin films.  The research supported by this award was designed to implement optimized structures of slow wave transmission lines as building blocks of compact RF passives and pattern ferromagnetic thin film in nanometer scale with improved ferromagnetic resonance frequency (FMR) for high frequency applications. With the integration of multiple thin film materials (e.g., Py and PZT), the results of our experiments gave us a number of new insights into the efficient design of frequency reconfigurable RF passives with not only more tuning flexibility and range, but also led to new functionalities that were not able to be achieve before (e.g., constant characteristic impedance). In particular, we learned how to design low loss slow wave transmission lines with  the optimized geometry structures, and how to improve the FMR of ferromagnetic thin film with the self-biased shape anisotropy field introduced by Nano-patterning ferromagnetic films in large aspect ratio.  We also learned about the electrical tunability of ferroelectric and ferromagnetic film with DC voltage and current, respectively.
